articles.headline: A Faded Piece of Papyrus Refers to Jesus’ Wife
articles.snippet: A Harvard historian of early Christianity said the papyrus, written in Coptic in the fourth century, contains a phrase never seen in any piece of Scripture: “Jesus said to them, ‘My wife ...’ ”
articles.abstract: A Harvard historian of early Christianity said the papyrus, written in Coptic in the fourth century, contains a phrase never seen in any piece of Scripture: “Jesus said to them, ‘My wife ...’ ”
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — A historian of early Christianity at Harvard Divinity School has identified a scrap of papyrus that she says was written in Coptic in the fourth century and contains a phrase never seen in any piece of Scripture: “Jesus said to them, ‘My wife ...’ ”

articles.headline: Euro or No, Economics of Everyday Greek Life Is Eroding
articles.snippet: Even if Greece gets yet another lifeline from its European partners, many Greeks have reached their own conclusion: It doesn’t matter, because of deep-seated problems.
articles.abstract: Even if Greece gets yet another lifeline from its European partners, many Greeks have reached their own conclusion: It doesn’t matter, because of deep-seated problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEVIDI, Greece — Gregoris Skouros stepped out of the sawed-off cargo container that hard times have forced him to make his home in on an agricultural plain near this tiny village, a two-hour drive south of Athens.

articles.headline: Russia Demands U.S. End Support of Democracy Groups
articles.snippet: The Kremlin views American financial support for a wide range of civil society programs as thinly veiled meddling in the country’s internal affairs.
articles.abstract: The Kremlin views American financial support for a wide range of civil society programs as thinly veiled meddling in the country’s internal affairs.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia has ordered the United States to end its financial support for a wide range of pro-democracy, public health and other civil society programs here, in an aggressive step by the Kremlin to halt what it views as American meddling in its internal affairs.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Executive at Goldman Is Retiring
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs said Tuesday that David A. Viniar, the bank’s longtime chief financial officer, would retire at the end of January and be replaced by Harvey Schwartz, a senior executive at the bank.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs said Tuesday that David A. Viniar, the bank’s longtime chief financial officer, would retire at the end of January and be replaced by Harvey Schwartz, a senior executive at the bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs introduced on Tuesday what may be the first of the next generation of leaders to run the storied Wall Street firm, saying that its longtime chief financial officer, David A. Viniar, would retire at the end of January and be replaced by Harvey M. Schwartz, a 48-year-old executive.

articles.headline: The Great American Tax Debate
articles.snippet: Maybe the way to start building a consensus about how much people should be taxed is to make the connection between the taxes people pay and the benefits they finance.
articles.abstract: Maybe the way to start building a consensus about how much people should be taxed is to make the connection between the taxes people pay and the benefits they finance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Come November, the economy — and who would be better to fix it — will probably be at the forefront of voters’ minds. But like pretty much every election of the last 60 years, voters’ choice will be colored by their views about taxes. If you believe the rich pay too little, chances are you will vote for Barack Obama. If you think tax rates on wealthy Americans are still too high, you will vote for Mitt Romney instead. Speaking to his donors at a fund-raiser, Mr. Romney argued he has no chance of gaining the vote of the nearly half of Americans who pay no federal income tax. But he probably has a good chance of capturing the vote of their fellow citizens who think paying no tax is unfair.

articles.headline: The iPhone 5 Scores Well, With a Quibble
articles.snippet: Apple has upgraded nearly every feature on the iPhone 5, but there’s a problem with universal compatibility.
articles.abstract: Apple has upgraded nearly every feature on the iPhone 5, but there’s a problem with universal compatibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you were taking a college course called iPhone 101, your professor might identify three factors that have made Apple’s smartphone a mega-success.

articles.headline: Samsung-Apple Fight Moves to Marketing
articles.snippet: Samsung’s campaign takes on the iPhone 5 directly, claiming its new Galaxy phone is better.
articles.abstract: Samsung’s campaign takes on the iPhone 5 directly, claiming its new Galaxy phone is better.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samsung may have lost the most recent round in the United States in its legal fight with Apple over cellphone technology, but that hasn’t stopped it from mounting a new assault against Apple that relies on a more public tactic — full-page ads.
articles.byline: By Tanzina Vega and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Media Chiefs Form Venture to E-Publish
articles.snippet: Two powerful entertainment moguls, Scott Rudin, the film and theater producer, and Barry Diller, the chairman of IAC/InterActiveCorp, are entering the turbulent world of book publishing.
articles.abstract: Two powerful entertainment moguls, Scott Rudin, the film and theater producer, and Barry Diller, the chairman of IAC/InterActiveCorp, are entering the turbulent world of book publishing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two powerful entertainment moguls, Scott Rudin, the film and theater producer, and Barry Diller, the chairman of IAC/InterActiveCorp, are joining together to enter the turbulent world of book publishing.

articles.headline: Next School Crisis for Chicago: Pension Fund Is Running Dry
articles.snippet: The Chicago Teachers’ Pension Fund is paying out more than $1 billion a year — much more than it has been taking in — and experts say the fund could collapse within a few years.
articles.abstract: The Chicago Teachers’ Pension Fund is paying out more than $1 billion a year — much more than it has been taking in — and experts say the fund could collapse within a few years.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the most vexing problems for Chicago and its teachers went virtually unmentioned during the strike: The pension fund is about to hit a wall.
